title: syscall: missing Errno on openbsd/386, openbsd/arm and openbsd/amd64

labels.name: compiler/runtime
labels.description: Issues related to the Go compiler and/or runtime.

body:
The syscall package is missing `EBADMSG`, `ENOTRECOVERABLE`, `EOWNERDEAD` and `EPROTO` on openbsd/386, openbsd/arm and openbsd/amd64. These are the earliest OpenBSD ports and they did not exist in the system headers when the relevant `zerror_*` file was generated. Given syscall is largely frozen, these have not been recently regenerated or updated.

Given that these already exist for all other ports, it makes sense to include them for consistency.

Issue noted by  Kirill Korinsky.

title: x/pkgsite: package removal request for github.com/danny-kuehn/wordgen

milestone.title: Unreleased
milestone.description: Issues that do not affect released Go code and binaries.

body: This source is no longer available, it was replaced by: https://github.com/wordgen/wordgen

title: x/tools/gopls: organizeImports does not find package after changing its name

labels.name: gopls
labels.description: Issues related to the Go language server, gopls.

labels.name: Tools
labels.description: This label describes issues relating to any tools in the x/tools repository.

body:

```shell
PKG_CONFIG='pkg-config'
GOGCCFLAGS='-fPIC -m64 -pthread -Wl,--no-gc-sections -fmessage-length=0 -ffile-prefix-map=/tmp/go-build4255810886=/tmp/go-build -gno-record-gcc-switches'
```


### What did you do?

I created a tiny Go project with the following 3 files:

go.mod:
```
module hello

go 1.22
```

hello1.go:
```go
package main

import (
	"fmt"
)

func main() {
	fmt.Println("hey, what’s up?")
}
```

internal/foo/foo.go:
```
package bar                  
 
func Bar() {}
func Baz() {}
```

Note how internal/foo/foo.go contains “package bar”, which I’ll later correct.

### What did you see happen?

I opened Emacs on hello1.go, then:
1. Added `foo.Bar()` to `func main()`, save the file to trigger organizeImports
    * This has no visible effect, but is a necessary step to reproduce the bug.
1. Opened internal/foo/foo.go as well
3. Changed “package bar” to “package foo”
4. Switched to the hello1.go buffer
5. Save hello1.go again to trigger organizeImports
7. The expected `internal/foo/foo` import is not added.

### What did you expect to see?

I would have expected gopls to add the internal/foo/foo import.

Restarting gopls using `M-x eglot` helps — afterwards the organizeImports action succeeds.

### Editor and settings

Emacs 29 with go-ts-mode and eglot
